description: Uncertain; perhaps an alteration of queme. The English Dialect Dictionary has a citation of "quim and cosh" from 1723 which it glosses as "intimate and familiar". Compare also quaint, cunt. Derivation from Welsh cwm (“hollow”) is sometimes suggested, but the OED notes that this is "unlikely on both semantic and phonological grounds".

entries.meaning: (vulgar, slang) The female genitalia; the vulva.
examples: For one day, when amusing herself with this whim
The carrot it snapped, and part stuck in her quim.

entries.meaning: (vulgar, derogatory) An extremely unpleasant or objectionable person.

description: Borrowed from Scots queem. Compare English queem.
